page.text: Description of the development (include all of the following that are known at the time of the
Location relative to major elements of the existing transportation system (e.g., the site is
located in the southwest quadrant of the intersection of Main Street/ First Street, 600
metres from the Maple Street Rapid Transit Station);
Existing land uses or permitted use provisions in the Official Plan, Zoning By-law, etc.;
Proposed land uses and relevant planning regulations to be used in the analysis;
Proposed development size (building size, number of residential units, etc.) and location
Proposed number of parking spaces (not relevant for Registration of Plans of
Proposed access points and type of access (full turns, right-in/ right-out, turning
Horizon years (include reference to phased development).
The TB must include a key plan that shows the general location of the development in relation to
the surrounding area. The TB must also provide a draft site plan or development concept of a
suitable scale that shows the general location of the development and the proposed access
locations. If the proposed development/redevelopment is to be constructed in phases, a description
must be provided for each phase, identifying the proposed timing of implementation.
Existing roads and ramps in the study area, including jurisdiction, classification, number
of lanes, and posted speed limit;
Existing intersections, indicating type of control, lane configurations, turning restrictions,
and any other relevant data (e.g., extraordinary lane widths, grades, etc.);
Existing access points to adjacent developments (both sides of all roads bordering the
Existing transit system, including stations and stops;
Existing on- and off-road bicycle facilities and pedestrian sidewalks and pathway
Major trip generators/ attractors within the Study Area should be indicated.
The TB report must include figures documenting the existing travel demands by. A photographic
inventory of the transportation network elements in the vicinity of the proposed access points would
be beneficial to staff in their review of the Consultant’s report.
Qualitative assessment of impacts on capacity; non-auto modes; on-site circulation;

text.b: Mitigation Measures and Site Design Characteristics (Sections 6.0, 7.0 and 8.0)

page.text: The TB must identify all mitigation measures required to offset network impacts from the
development. The TB must also identify key site design features required to implement the Official
Plan and Transportation Master Plan policies regarding site development.
The TB must include all of the following, where they are required by the subject development:
Location and timing of proposed changes to existing traffic controls at intersections
(e.g., new traffic signals, Stop signs, etc.);
Mitigation measures required to offset impacts on the surface and Rapid Transit
New or modified elements of the bicycle and pedestrian networks;
Proposed TDM features or programs to support the site development.
Distribution of Site Traffic at Accesses
Appendix A: OC Transpo Route Maps and Bus Stop Locations
An A&W restaurant is proposed at 41 Edgewater Street, located in the east quadrant of the
intersection of Terry Fox Drive and Edgewater Street. The area of the site is approximately 1.44ha
and the area of the portion of the site to be amended is approximately 0.27ha. The site is currently
occupied by a disused gas bar, an Eastside Mario’s Restaurant, a Swiss Chalet Restaurant, and a
D’Arcy McGees Irish Pub. The proposed development will replace the disused gas bar.
The site is bounded by Terry Fox Drive and Walter Baker Park to the south and west, Edgewater
Street and an Esso gas station to the north, and several light industrial and commercial
developments to the east. Under the City of Ottawa’s Zoning By-law, the site is designated as a
Subzone 2 of a General Industrial Zone (IG2), which permits the following land uses:
The proposed land uses (drive-through facility and restaurant) are permitted on the subject site
under the Zoning By-law. The site location is shown in Figure 1.
The proposed restaurant will have a GFA of 173m
and a drive-through facility with a capacity for
12 cars. An additional 20 parking spaces will be added to the existing parking lot adjacent to the
Eastside Mario’s Restaurant. Access to the development will be from two existing unsignalized
accesses on Edgewater Street and a signalized access on Terry Fox Drive. The proposed site plan
The restaurant is planned for opening in 2011.
Study area intersections to be considered in this report were confirmed with City staff. It was
determined that the study area should include the two existing unsignalized site accesses on
Edgewater Street, the signalized site access on Terry Fox Drive, and intersection of Terry Fox
The study will examine the existing and total traffic conditions during the weekday AM and PM
peak hours. These time periods are considered to represent the ‘worst-case’ combination of site-
generated traffic and adjacent street traffic.
The methodologies used to analyze the transportation impacts of the proposed development are
• An operational evaluation of intersection performance under the background and total traffic
conditions has been completed for the weekday AM and PM peak hours;
• Provisions for non-auto travel modes have been assessed, including integration with local
transit service, and connections with the local pedestrian and bicycle networks;
• The proposed on-site design has been reviewed in terms of access, parking facilities and
• An evaluation of the development with respect to its conformity with Transportation Demand
Edgewater Street is classified as a collector roadway, and has a two-lane rural cross-section. The
Terry Fox Drive is a north-south arterial roadway extending between Richardson Side Road in the
north and Eagleson Road in the south. Within the study area, Terry Fox Drive has a four-lane
urban cross section with a posted speed of 70 km/h.
In the vicinity of the subject site, there are several driveway accesses on both sides of Edgewater
Street serving a number of commercial and light industrial developments.
The Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street intersection is signalized, with designated left turn lanes
provided on all four approaches. A designated right turn lane is provided on the southbound
approach on Terry Fox Drive. A designated right turn lane for the two site accesses on Edgewater
Street extends back to the Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street intersection.
The existing site access on Terry Fox Drive is signalized and aligned opposite an access to Walter
Baker Park, which is located southwest of the subject site. Designated left turn lanes are provided
The two unsignalized accesses on Edgewater Street have stop control on the side streets.
Movements at the westernmost access are limited to right-in, right-out movements by the presence
of a curbed median which prevents left turns.
No sidewalk is provided on Edgewater Street in the vicinity of the subject site.
Concrete sidewalk and an asphalt boulevard are provided along the north side of the section of
Terry Fox Drive adjacent to the site. An off-road multi-use pathway is provided along the south site
of Terry Fox Drive. The Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street intersection and the signalized site
access on Terry Fox Drive are connected to the existing on-site parking lot by asphalt sidewalk.
Crosswalks are provided on all arms of the Terry Fox/Edgewater Street intersection, and all arms
of the 41 Edgewater Street/Walter Baker Park access on Terry Fox Drive.
Terry Fox Drive is a designated Spine or City-Wide Route in the City of Ottawa’s Ottawa Cycling
Plan (OCP), and identifies that the section of Terry Fox Drive adjacent to the subject site is served
with on-road bicycle lanes in both directions. No further provision of cycling facilities is
recommended in the OCP. An off-road multi-use pathway located on the south side of Terry Fox
Drive is also available for cycling purposes.
Edgewater Street has no official designation in the OCP. Designated cycling facilities are not
provided along Edgewater Street, and there is no recommendation in the OCP to provide cycling
A copy of the current OC Transpo route map for the surrounding area and a bus stop location map
centered on the subject site are included in Appendix A.
Regular route 118 and rural express route 263 currently service the section of Terry Fox Drive
adjacent to the subject site. Route 118 provides a link between Kanata and downtown Ottawa via
Hurdman bus station. Route 263 provides a direct express link from Stittsville to downtown Ottawa
via Highway 417 during a.m. peak hours, and runs in the opposite direction during p.m. peak
Existing bus stops #6381 and #6382 are located on Terry Fox Drive at a walking distance of less
than 100m from the main entrance to the proposed restaurant. Bus routes 118 and 263 service
Existing traffic volumes within the study area were taken from a traffic count carried out by the City
July 2010 at the Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street/Walter Baker Park
intersection. Novatech also carried out a 6-hour traffic count on Tuesday 24
existing signalized site access on Terry Fox Drive, and a PM peak hour count on Wednesday 25
August at the existing unsignalized accesses on Edgewater Street.
All of the aforementioned traffic counts are included as Appendix B, and existing traffic volumes
within the study area are shown in Figure 3.
Site-generated traffic has been estimated using the vehicle trip rates identified in the ITE Trip
Generation Manual. These rates are related to the GFA of the proposed restaurant.
The proposed development is expected to generate primary and pass-by trips. Primary trips are
made for the specific purpose of visiting the site. Pass-by trips are made as an intermediate stop
on the way to another destination. The percentage of pass-by trips has been estimated using the
rate identified in the ITE Trip Generation Handbook (7
Edition) for the ITE “Fast Food Restaurant”
land use. Primary and pass-by trips are summarized as follows for the weekday AM and weekday
The assumed distribution of pass-by trips has been based on existing traffic patterns. The
assumed distribution of primary trips has been derived from the type and density of the
surrounding land uses, traffic conditions on the surrounding road network. The trip distribution
• 20% to/from the east via Edgewater Street (Hazeldean Road);
• 40% to/from the north via Terry Fox Drive (Hwy 417);
• 40% to/from the south via Terry Fox Drive (Hazeldean Rd, Eagleson Rd).

text.b: Pass-by trips - AM Peak Hour (PM Peak Hour)

page.text: • 10% (10%) from the east via Edgewater Street (Hazeldean Road);
• 35% (50%) from the north via Terry Fox Drive (Hwy 417);
• 55% (40%) from the south via Terry Fox drive (Hazeldean Rd, Eagleson Rd).
The assumed distribution of site-generated traffic across the site accesses is based on the access
configuration, observed driver behaviour at this location, and the principles of logical trip routing.
The distribution is summarized in the following table.

text.b: Table 2: Distribution of Site Traffic at Accesses

page.text: Site generated traffic volumes are shown in Figure 4 for the weekday AM and PM peak hours.
The types of analysis undertaken to assess the transportation impacts of the revised development
are consistent with the requirements of the Ottawa Transportation Impact Assessment (TIA)
An operational evaluation of the Edgewater Street/Terry Fox Drive intersection and the site
accesses have been completed for the existing and total traffic scenarios using the Synchro 6.0
software package. This software uses methodology from the Highway Capacity Manual 2000
(HCM), published by the Transportation Research Board, to evaluate signalized and unsignalized
Intersection operating conditions are commonly described in terms of a Level of Service (LOS).
LOS is a quality measure of speed, freedom to manoeuvre, interruptions, comfort and
convenience. Letters are assigned to six levels, with LOS ‘A’ representing optimal operating
conditions and LOS ‘F’ representing failing operating conditions.
The City of Ottawa has adopted criteria that directly relate the LOS of a signalized intersection to a
volume to capacity (v/c) ratio. Vehicle capacity is defined as the maximum number of vehicles that
can pass a given point during a specified period under prevailing traffic conditions. The City’s
The TIA guidelines state that mitigation measures are required where v/c ratios exceed 0.90,
except in the Urban Core where 1.0 is acceptable.
The LOS for an unsignalized intersection is based on average control delay and is defined for
individual movements. Control delay includes initial deceleration, queue move-up time, stopped
time and final acceleration. The HCM presents the following criteria relating the LOS for individual
In this study, movements at signalized and unsignalized intersections have been evaluated in
terms of the LOS as defined in the foregoing tables. Mitigation measures in the form of additional
lane capacity and/or signal adjustments have been identified for movements with a LOS E or F.
The analysis of the existing traffic condition is based on 2010 traffic counts, existing lane
configurations, and traffic signal timing plans obtained from the Public Works & Services
Expected operating conditions for movements with the highest v/c ratio or longest delay at the
study area intersections and accesses are summarized in the following table for the weekday AM
and PM peak hours. Detailed output from the Synchro software is provided in Appendix C.

text.b: Table 3: Intersection Analysis – Existing Traffic Condition

page.text: The analysis results indicate that all study area intersections and accesses will operate with
acceptable LOS during AM and PM peak hours. At the Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street
intersection, a maximum queue length of 70m is expected on the southbound left-turn approach
during the AM peak. This queue length exceeds the available storage capacity of 55m. By re-
optimizing the existing signal timing splits at this intersection the 70m queue is expected to reduce
to 55m, with no adverse effect on any other approach.
Queue lengths on all other approaches can be accommodated within their respective storage
lengths, and no blocking is anticipated. Delays at the unsignalized accesses on Edgewater Street
are expected to be very short, with a maximum delay of 11 seconds expected at the full movement
access during the PM peak. No delay is expected at either access during the AM peak, as the
existing on-site development is closed and not generating any traffic at that time.
The analysis of the existing traffic condition is based on 2010 traffic counts, existing lane
configurations, and traffic signal timing plans obtained from the Public Works & Services
Department for each signalized intersection. For the purpose of this analysis, the signal timing
splits at the Terry Fox/Edgewater Street intersection have been re-optimized to reflect the
anticipated change in traffic conditions. Total traffic volumes have been calculated by adding the
site-generated traffic volumes to the existing traffic volumes. Total traffic volumes for the weekday
AM and weekday PM peak are shown in Figure 5.
Expected operating conditions for movements with the highest v/c ratio or longest delay at the
study area intersections and accesses are summarized in the following table for the weekday AM
and PM peak hours. Detailed output from the Synchro software is provided in Appendix C.

text.b: Table 4: Intersection Analysis – Total Traffic Condition

page.text: The addition of site-generated traffic is expected to result in very marginal increases to the v/c
ratios and delays at the study area intersections and accesses during peak hours. Acceptable
levels of service (LOS) are anticipated for all movements during the peak hour. At the Terry Fox
Drive/Edgewater Street approach, a maximum queue length of 80m is expected on the southbound
left-turn approach during the weekday AM peak hour. This queue length exceeds the available
storage capacity of 55m. By adding a protected left turn phase for this movement during the AM
peak, the 80m queue is expected to reduce to 45m, with no adverse effect on any other approach.
Queue lengths on all other approaches can be accommodated within their respective storage
lengths, and no blocking is anticipated. Similar to the existing traffic condition, delays at the
unsignalized accesses on Edgewater Street are expected to be very short, with a maximum delay
of 12 seconds expected at the full movement access during the AM peak hour. All movements at
the unsignalized accesses are expected to operate with acceptable levels of service.
The existing asphalt sidewalk connecting the existing parking lot to the sidewalk on Terry Fox Drive
is to be removed and replaced with a 1.5m wide concrete sidewalk. This new sidewalk will provide
a more direct link between the new development and the existing sidewalk on Terry Fox Drive, as
shown in Figure 2. A 1.0m wide sidewalk will be provided on-site to assist pedestrian circulation
As described in Section 3.4, OC Transpo bus stops #6381 and #6382 are located on Terry Fox
Drive directly across from the subject site at a walking distance of 100m. This is well within the OC
Transpo maximum recommended walking distance of 400m.
There are three existing accesses to 41 Edgewater Street, one of which is signalized. The
proposed development will be served by all three accesses.
The signalized access is located on Terry Fox Drive approximately 250m south of the Terry Fox
Drive/Edgewater Street intersection, measured centerline to centerline. The two other accesses
are unsignalized, and located on Edgewater Street approximately 55m and 95m east of the Terry
Fox Drive/Edgewater Street intersection, measured centreline to centreline. The access closest to
this intersection is limited to right-in, right-out (RIRO) movements only, with a curbed median
preventing left turns at the access.
As part of this development, the centreline of the full-movement unsignalized access on Edgewater
Street will be relocated 3 metres to the east. The RIRO access will remain at the same location.
New curb radii of 5m will be provided at the RIRO access, and curb radii of 7m and 8m will be
provided at the full-movement access. Depressed curb will be maintained across the full width of
No changes are proposed for the signalized access on Terry Fox Drive.
The City of Ottawa’s 2008 Zoning By-law identifies a minimum parking requirement of 10 spaces
for this development. Based on the GFA of the restaurant, a total of 18 parking spaces
are required for this development. As shown on Figure 2, a total of 20 parking spaces are to be
provided on site, thereby satisfying the Zoning By-Law minimum requirements for the development.
The City of Ottawa’s 2003 Traffic and Parking By-Law requires a parking lot with 20-99 spaces to
provide at least one handicap accessible space. This space is shown in Figure 2, located as close
as possible to the entrances of the main school building.
The City of Ottawa Zoning By-Law identifies a minimum bicycle parking requirement of one space
GFA for this development. Based on the GFA of the restaurant, one bicycle parking
space is required for this development. The location of on-site bicycle parking will be dealt with at
The Zoning By-Law includes queuing space requirements for drive-through facilities. A minimum of
7 spaces are required before the order board and a minimum of 4 spaces are required between the
order board and pick-up window. All queuing spaces must be 3 meters wide and 5.7 meters long.
A total of 12 adequately sized vehicle queuing spaces will be provided, including 8 spaces before
the order board and 4 spaces between the order board and pick-up window. The planned number
of queuing spaces satisfies the minimum requirements of the Zoning By-Law.
The surrounding land uses primarily consist of light industrial and commercial development.
Arterial and collector roadways provide direct access to the subject site. Neighbourhood infiltration
is not anticipated as a result of site generated traffic.
The proposed on-site parking satisfies the anticipated parking demand that will be generated by
the new restaurant. Parking infiltration onto study area roadways is not anticipated.
The City of Ottawa is developing a comprehensive Transportation Demand Management (TDM)
strategy as part of its efforts to reduce automobile dependency. TDM measures can reduce
transportation infrastructure requirements by encouraging people to change their travel mode,
The proposed development conforms to the City’s TDM initiatives by providing easy access for
sustainable travel modes, as described in Section 6.0.
Based on the results of the foregoing analysis, the main conclusions and recommendations of this
• All study area intersections and accesses currently operate with acceptable levels of service in
the weekday AM and PM peak hours;
• Site-generated traffic will result in very marginal increases to v/c ratios, queue lengths and
delays at the study area intersections and accesses;
• All study area intersections and accesses are expected to operate with acceptable levels of
service in the weekday AM and PM peak hours with the addition of site-generated traffic;
• By adding a protected left turn phase for the southbound movement at the during the AM peak,
it is anticipated that all queue lengths at the Terry Fox Drive/Edgewater Street intersection can
be accommodated within existing storage lengths;
• The proposed on-site parking and drive-through facility meet the minimum requirements of the
• Following completion of the development, no adverse community impacts are anticipated;
• The development conforms to the City’s TDM initiatives by providing easy access for
